repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: COVID-19 Pandemic Collection

physdesc.extent: Of the 166 digital objects, one digital object comprises 98 files.

did.abstract: The novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19 in infected patients, was identified in late 2019 in Wuhan, China. By February 2020, the virus had spread outside of China into Europe and other areas of the world, causing stay-at-home orders to be implemented, and schools and non-essential businesses to close. On March 10, 2020, Tufts University announced that all classes would be moved online, and that all on-campus facilities would be closed for the remainder of the semester, requiring students to move out of dormitories by the end of the week. The COVID-19 Pandemic Collection contains material documenting COVID-19 and its impact on faculty, staff, and students at Tufts University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Ana Sophia Ascota, 2020, MS-2020-062; Jeffrey Rawitsch, 2020, accession MS-2020-063; Lauren Soherr, 2020, accession MS-2020-065; Jake Zaslav, 2020, MS-2020-067; Luke Allocco, 2020, accession MS-2020-068; Silvia Bottinelli, 2020, accession MS-2020-069; Annie Ziwen Yin, 2020, MS-2021-001; Elizabeth Mainiero, 2020, MS-2021-002; Sarah Wiener, 2020, MS-2021-003; Tony Monaco, 2020, UA-2021-005; John Wescott, 2020, UA-2021-002.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19 in infected patients, was identified in late 2019 in Wuhan, China. It was known for being highly contagious, as well as for causing fever and respiratory symptoms in infected patients. By February 2020, the virus had spread outside of China into Europe and other areas of the world, causing stay-at-home orders to be implemented, and schools and non-essential businesses to close. In the United States, the closure of most businesses caused a rapid spike in unemployment across the country.

On March 10, 2020, Tufts University announced that all classes would be moved online, and that all on-campus facilities would be closed for the remainder of the semester, requiring students to move out of dormitories by the end of the week. Commencement for graduating students was subsequently moved online, with a later in-person date to be announced when it was safe to do so. The university made changes to its academic grading system, with faculty voting to allow undergraduate students to opt-in to a pass/fail grading system for any class regardless of any requirements. On March 15, 2020, the university announced that all staff would begin working remotely by March 17, 2020 unless their work required them to report to campus in order to maintain operational and academic continuity. The university additionally opened up its residence halls to local hospitals to house patients, first responders, and essential workers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: COVID-19 Pandemic Collection, 2020. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Records and Accesioning Archivist, Jane Kelly, in 2020. Web crawls were managed using Archive-It by Jane Kelly and Digital Archivist, Margaret Peachy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The COVID-19 Pandemic Collection contains material documenting COVID-19 and its impact on faculty, staff, and students at Tufts University. Photographs, videos, diaries, written reflections, and web captures document the Tufts Medford campus, faculty and staff work, and how students' lives changes a result of disruption to the Spring 2020 semester. The vast majority of materials in this collection were created in 2020. There are a few items digitized in 2020, for which the originals date to 1949 -- 1953 and 2003, documenting the life of alumnus Vincent Maniero.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish.

did.unittitle: COVID-19 pandemic collection

physdesc.extent: Of the 166 digital objects, one digital object comprises 98 files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged chronologically in the order of accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material documenting COVID-19 and its impact on faculty, staff, and students at Tufts University.

did.unittitle: Tufts campus, graduation, and claps for essential workers photographs and videos

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Ana Sophia Acosta, April and June 2020, accession number MS-2020-062.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos and videos of the Tufts campus and New York City during the COVID-19 pandemic. This material includes photos and videos of the Illumination Ceremony, a Tufts tradition typically celebrated on the eve of Commencement; students moving out of campus housing; an unofficial graduation ceremony; and New York City residents clapping for essential workers. Item-level description of the photographs and videos was provided by Ana Sophia Acosta.

acqinfo.p: Transferred by Jeffrey Rawitsch, April 2020, accession number MS-2020-063.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lyric sheet and audio recording created by Jeffrey Rawitsch, Granoff Music Center manager, in Arlington, Massachusetts as a public service announcement about COVID-19. Set to "Uptown Funk" as recorded by Mark Ronson, featuring Bruno Mars.

acqinfo.p: Transferred by Lauren Soherr, May 2020, accession number MS-2020-065.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Video diary kept by Lauren Soherr during her fourteen day self-isolation after returning from Tufts to her home in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

did.unittitle: Quarantine day one video
Quarantine day three video
Corona update video
Jake Zaslav interview with Umbrella Pine

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Jake Zaslav, April and July 2020, accession number MS-2020-067.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "A Conversation with Umbrella Pine" is an interview-based documentary from director Jake Zaslav (Arts and Sciences, 2020) with Umbrella Pine, Magdalena Abrego and Allison Burik's contemporary improvisation duo. Produced for Professor Natalie Minik's course, "FMS-037 Documentary History and Practice," the film documents the challenges performing musicians faced during the COVID-19 pandemic.

did.unittitle: A conversation with Umbrella Pine

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: File available upon request. Please contact DCA for access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal reflection detailing Luke Allocco's experiences following the announcement of the University's closure in March 2020 and photographs of various campus locations. Item-level description of the photographs was provided by the donor.

scopecontent.p: Another shot of the empty Tisch Library, March 11, 2020. Going to the library seemed to be the last thing on students' minds after the university's announcement.

did.unittitle: Senior Week table tents in Tisch Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These table tents in Tisch Library seemed suddenly out of place as events such as Senior Week were thrown into uncertainty by the pandemic.

did.unittitle: Students outside Tisch Library during power outage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To make matters more chaotic, the uphill portion of campus suffered a power outage the morning after the closure announcement was made. Classes that were scheduled to meet in Tisch Library congregated outside waiting for news. Professor Lee Edelman of the FMS Department is on the left side in green. Professor Jeffrey Berry of the Political Science Department is in the center of the photo with his back to the camera. Professor Berry dismissed us a few minutes after this photo was taken. His final message to us was "I didn't want to end class this way, but at least we're in the sunshine." I had two more classes scheduled for the following day; both were cancelled, bringing a swift end to the in-person classes of my junior year.

did.unittitle: Public health signs posted in Tisch Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Public health messaging increased in the wake of the pandemic. These signs were posted in the Tisch Library G Level men's restroom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A shattered bottle of Corona Extra on the sidewalk outside Lewis Hall (Powder House side).

did.unittitle: Tisch Library closing sign

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The University initially announced that Tisch Library would be restricted to students and staff beginning on March 16. The announcement was revised a day later to institute a complete closure of the library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Commons Marketplace is pictured. Along with Dewick, the Commons was the only dining location to remain open after the university closed. Chairs were removed after Massachusetts banned dining inside restaurants.

did.unittitle: COVID-19 reflections
COVID-19 pandemic obituaries

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Silvia Bottinelli, June 2020, accession number MS-2020-069.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TRT World interview with School of Museum of Fine Arts professor, Silvia Bottinnelli, on the critic and curator Germano Celant, who died of coronavirus.

did.unittitle: As Life Goes On student film

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Annie Ziwen Yin, June 2020, accession number MS-2021-001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Film project created by Annie Ziwen Yin for Film and Media Studies 34: Producing for Film. Participants filmed snippets of their lives during the COVID-19 pandemic and Yin compiled and edited the footage. Participants, who were both Tufts and non-Tufts students, were located in Chicago, Illinois; Longmeadow, New York; New York City, New York; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Seattle, Washington; Brisbane, Australia; Beijing, China; Copenhagen, Denmark; Astana, Kazakhstan; and Singapore.

did.unittitle: Beth and Vincent Maniero letters and photographs

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Elizabeth Mainiero, July 2020, accession number MS-2021-002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters written by Beth Mainiero to her husband, Vincent Mainiero, Tufts Class of 1953. Vincent was in a nursing home and because he was unable to use the phone due to his health or receive visits due to the pandemic, Beth wrote him letters. The letters recount Beth's day-to-day activities during the pandemic; greetings from friends and family; summaries of communications from the nursing home; and information about Vincent's health. Vincent died of COVID-19 on May 12, 2020. This material also includes scanned photographs of Vincent, a scanned map of the Tufts campus, and statistics regarding nursing home deaths due to COVID-19 in Milford, Connecticut.

Tufts Community Union Senate survey, report, and raw data

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Sarah Weiner, July 2020, accession number MS-2021-003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts Community Union Senate survey, report, and raw data, consisting of survey questions and responses, a publicly distributed final narrative report, and the raw data. The survey asked students what they thought did and did not go well during the start of the pandemic in Spring 2020, fears and concerns about the upcoming Fall 2020 semester, and what aspects of student life were most important to try to maintain in the Fall 2020 semester.

did.unittitle: Fall 2020 student feedback survey report
Fall 2020 student feedback survey default report
Fall 2020 survey raw data
Tony Monaco correspondence and photographs

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Tony Monaco, June 2020, accession number UA-2021-005.

did.unittitle: Tufts University Social Collective socially distanced graduation and Senior Week material

physdesc.extent: Of the three digital objects in this file, one digital object comprises 98 files.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by John Wescott, June 2020, accession number UA-2021-002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos and videos depicting a socially distanced graduation ceremony for the graduating members of the Tufts University Social Collective (TUSC) and Senior Week material created by TUSC. The Senior Week material consists of items mailed to each graduating student in a "Senior Week in a Box" and a list of the contents.

did.unittitle: Socially distanced graduation ceremony photographs and videos
Senior Week in a Box
Senior Week in a Box insert
Senior Week 2020 flyer
Commencement website capture

physdesc.extent: WARC file contains captured of each school's 2020 commencement ceremony, excluding the well-wishing videos submitted by friends, family, faculty, and staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This web capture represents the commencement ceremonies for each school at Tufts as they were held online in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The capture does not include the well-wisher videos submitted by family, friends, faculty, and staff to each school.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Webrecorder Player is needed to playback the website content. Instuctions for download and use are in the Box folder linked from this record.

did.unittitle: COVID-19 pandemic Tufts-branded face masks

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Office for Campus Life, 2021, accession UA-2021-022.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tisch College 2020 election mask marked "VOTE," an SMFA at Tufts mask, and Africana Center mask. The Africana Center mask is part of a care package that also includes hand sanitizer, a Black Lives Matter bracelet, and Africana Center rubber ID card holder.

did.unittitle: Web crawls

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by the date a website was first crawled.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series represents a collection of websites regarding Tufts University's response to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Websites include official University communications, news items reporting on Tufts' response, student-published articles, and social media posts.

The collection will grow as the pandemic continues, and the finding aid will be updated on a regular basis to reflect addtions. To see the current state of the web collection, follow the link in the Other Finding Aids note for this series to its Archive-It landing page.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: To see all of websites crawled as part of the Tufts response to COVID-19 web collection, please visit https://archive-it.org/collections/13686
